title: Teenager smuggled into UK three years ago fears for his life if he’s sent back
text:
Samet, 18, was trafficked into the UK in the back of a lorry (Picture: Tom Wren/SWNS)

A boy who was smuggled into the UK in the back of a lorry is being threatened with deportation just weeks after his 18th birthday.

Samet’s life back in Albania was one of horrific violence and abuse.

By 11, he was forced to beg on the streets, and by 15, he had been dragged by his father to Brussels, a notorious hub for people trafficking in the heart of Europe.

He managed to escape his father’s clutches in Belgium and tasted freedom for the first time after being found in a lorry in Bristol nearly three years ago.

After six months in a children’s home, social services sent Samet to live with John Stokes, a trusted local carer who has fostered nearly 80 troubled and vulnerable children in 30 years.

Since arriving in Bristol aged 15 with barely any English, Samet has transformed his life and is now fulfilling his dream of becoming a carpenter.

Foster carer John Stokes said Samet is one of the family now (Picture: Tom Wren/SWNS)

John says Samet has an ‘immense enthusiasm to turn his life around’ (Picture: Tom Wren/SWNS)

But within days of Samet turning 18 last month, the Home Office sent his dreams crashing, telling him his appeal to stay in the UK had been rejected.

Samet, who has been diagnosed with PTSD and struggles to talk about his journey to the UK, said he’s ‘scared’ he will be sent back to a country where he has nothing but trauma.

He nervously told Metro.co.uk: ‘I felt stressed when I got the letter. I feel scared now.

‘I don’t want to go back to Albania. I hope the Home Office change their mind. Life is good here with John.’

Mr Stokes said it feels as though the government has ‘picked someone up from a life raft just to throw them back in the sea’.

The carer, 66, claims the government is putting off decisions to grant asylum to unaccompanied child migrants until they turn 18.

Samet wants to become a carpenter and is ‘scared’ he will be sent back to Albania (Picture: Tom Wren/SWNS)

He said: ‘Because once they’re 18 they are not technically children and they’re easier to get out of the country.’

Mr Stokes said Samet has been ‘inspirational’ for other English boys in the care system because ‘despite the trauma he has an immense enthusiasm to turn his life around’.

He said: ‘He’s outstanding at college. He’s doing a second year carpentry course. All his results are outstanding.

‘He’s developed his English very well and he’s doing everything right basically.

‘But the main thing is, he has become part of the family.’

Mr Stokes was one of the UK’s first single male foster parents, but the fight to keep Samet in the country has made him doubt the whole system.

He said: ‘It calls into question whether after 30 years I should continue fostering because I don’t know how I can support them anymore.

‘I’ve got another Albanian lad who is 20 and he’s still with me. He’s been with me for four years.

‘They’ve both become part of the family. It may not be the most standard family but the two lads have been the most rewarding boys to work with because of their enthusiasm and keenness to succeed.’

A Home Office spokesperson would not go into Samet’s ongoing case, telling Metro.co.uk: ‘It would be inappropriate to comment whilst legal proceedings are ongoing.’

Mr Stokes has launched a campaign to help Samet on Change.org in the hope the government will ‘reconsider the life sentence they have given him’.
